metadata.title: Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis

the vertebral bodies rotate toward the convex side of the curve. in the thoracic spine
this results in a rib prominence (hump) posteriorly on the convex side of the curve and anteriorly on the concave side of the curve(1)
or correctable –defined: a reversible lateral curvature of the spine. this type of deviation can be reversed with forward or side bending or with a positional change

classification of idiopathic scoliosis –infantile idiopathic scoliosis—presents by the age of 3 years (29) –juvenile idiopathic scoliosis—presents between the ages of 3 years and 10 years (29) –adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (ais)—presents between the ages of 10 years and 18 years (30)

staging of scoliosis using the classification for early-  onset scoliosis (c-eos)  system: (29) –etiology -congenital/structural (c) -neuromuscular (m) -syndromic (s) -idiopathic (i) –coronal cobb angle -less than 20° (1) -20 to 50° (2) -51 to 90° (3) -greater than 90° (4) –maximum kyphosis -less than 20°(-) -20 to 50° (n) -greater than 50° (+) –progression modifier -less than 10° per year -10 to 20° per year -greater than 20° per year –example of using the c-eos  system -a 10-year-old  patient with a neuromuscular scoliosis with a 25° coronal curve having a 51°kyphosis with 12° progression would be labeled as 10m2+p1
description: A fixed (structural) lateral curvature of the spine > 10° in the coronal plane with onset near puberty and no known cause(2)

Structural scoliosis –Synonyms: Fixed or nonflexible –Defined: An irreversible lateral curvature of the spine with fixed rotation of the vertebrae. Typically, the vertebral bodies rotate toward the convex side of the curve. In the thoracic spine, this results in a rib prominence (hump) posteriorly on the convex side of the curve and anteriorly on the concave side of the curve(1)

Nonstructural scoliosis –Synonyms: Functional, postural, flexible, or correctable –Defined: A reversible lateral curvature of the spine. This type of deviation can be reversed with forward or side bending or with a positional change, such as lying supine(1)

Classification of idiopathic scoliosis –Infantile idiopathic scoliosis—presents by the age of 3 years (29) –Juvenile idiopathic scoliosis—presents between the ages of 3 years and 10 years (29) –Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS)—presents between the ages of 10 years and 18 years (30)

Staging of scoliosis using the Classification for Early-  Onset Scoliosis (C-EOS)  system: (29) –Etiology -Congenital/structural (C) -Neuromuscular (M) -Syndromic (S) -Idiopathic (I) –Coronal Cobb Angle -Less than 20° (1) -20 to 50° (2) -51 to 90° (3) -Greater than 90° (4) –Maximum Kyphosis -Less than 20°(-) -20 to 50° (N) -Greater than 50° (+) –Progression Modifier -Less than 10° per year  -10 to 20° per year -Greater than 20° per year –Example of using the C-EOS  system -A 10-year-old  patient with a neuromuscular scoliosis with a 25° coronal curve having a 51°kyphosis with 12° progression would be labeled as 10M2+P1

M41.Q76.3: congenital scoliosis due to congenital bony malformation

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified

Presentation/signs and symptoms  (the patient may present with some or all of the following signs and symptoms) –Lateral curvature of the spine and rotation of the vertebrae(2) –Asymmetrical pelvis/shoulders –Asymmetrical waistline –Rib hump/prominence –Prominent scapula –Asymmetrical spinal muscular extensibility/pliability –Muscle spasms –Tenderness to palpation of spinal soft tissue –Spinal joint hypermobility/hypomobility –Leg-length  discrepancy –Pain, if present, typically is mild(30) –Negative body image(2) –Fatigue after prolonged standing, walking, or activity –Antalgic gait –Asymmetry in transverse abdominal muscle thickness as determined by ultrasound imaging (17,22)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If the child/adolescent complains of pain, more serious pathology than scoliosis may be suspected. Refer back to physician as indicated

The evaluation below can serve as a screening tool/guide to identify a potential case of scoliosis as well as an evaluation tool for assessing children with AIS referred to physical therapy for pain management, strengthening, or stretching

causes: Ninety percent of scoliosis cases are considered idiopathic(3)
However, there is some evidence(multiple family members presenting with the condition) of a genetic component (30)
Other causes may be hormonal causes, asymmetric growth and/or muscle imbalance(30)
pathogenesis: AIS can lead to a stiff chest wall and a reduction in lung volume. Other complications can include corpulmonale, rightventricular dysfunction, and pulmonary hypertension(2)
risk factors: Incidence of scoliosis is the same in males and females; however, females are at higher risk of curve progression thanmales (10:1)(3)

Genetic factors have been suggested as a contributing risk factor in developing AIS. Authors of a 2014 study suggest thatgenetic variations of the CALM1  gene are associated with AIS susceptibility(18)

Results of a study conducted in Australia showed that adolescent ballet dancers were 12.4 times more likely to havescoliosis than age-matched  controls(9)–Thirty dancers and 30 nondancers participated–There was a higher rate of hypermobility in the dancer group than the nondancers (70%:3%); however, there was nostatistically significant relationship between hypermobility and scoliosis–There was no significant relationship between scoliosis and age of menarche, BMI, or hours of dance per week–The researchers concluded that adolescent dancers are at significantly higher risk of developing scoliosis than nondancersof the same age

overall contraindications precautions: The U.K. National Screening Committee updated its guidelines based on a systematic review of the literature through 2015 and concluded that no change was warranted to its policy that screening for AIS is not recommended(4) There is evidence to suggest that screening programs identify a higher proportion of individuals with more minor curves than would typically present outside screening. There is not a high level of evidence to suggest that treatment of a minor curvature will prevent progression(4) Referral after positive screening will lead to radiography, meaning that a proportion of individuals will have X-rays  they would not normally have had, on the basis of a test with poor predictive value(4) A lack of consensus on when treatment is indicated means there is also a risk that persons with AIS could receive unnecessary and ineffective treatments on the basis of the screening test(4)

In contrast, in its revised guidelines in 2016, the International Scientific Society on Scoliosis Orthopaedic and Rehabilitation Treatment (SOSORT) recommends that school screening programs for the early diagnosis of idiopathic scoliosis be implemented(5)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: If the child/adolescent complains of pain, more serious pathology than scoliosis may be suspected. Refer back to physician as indicated

The evaluation below can serve as a screening tool/guide to identify a potential case of scoliosis as well as an evaluation tool for assessing children with AIS referred to physical therapy for pain management, strengthening, or stretching

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Has the curvature progressed over time? How much? -Is surgical intervention or bracing an option at this time?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Bracing As a form of treatment, bracing continues to be a controversial topic. Some clinics utilize a thoraco-lumbo-sacral orthosis (TLSO) or a cervicothoraco-lumbo-sacral  orthosis (CTLSO) in the treatment of AIS, while others continue to monitor the curve Types of braces The Milwaukee Brace (CTLSO) is utilized to treat high thoracic curves (apex above T9). TLSOs are utilized to treat curves with an apex ≤ T9. LSOs are utilized to treat lumbar curves(6) The Osaka Medical College (OMC) Brace is a popular TLSO brace used in Japan that was developed in the 1970s. In a 2015 study, researchers found the OMC brace to be effective at changing curve progression if high compliance is maintained(15)The goal of bracing is to prevent curve progressionBrace wearing can be terminated when the child has reached skeletal maturity(1) Researchers in a 2014 study found that high compliance with wearing a brace can alter curve progression and decrease chance of surgery, while overnightonly  bracing and poor compliance are associated with a high rate of curve progression(13) A newer technique of ultrasound-assisted  brace casting has been found to be a radiation-free  way to check pressure level, location, and brace corrections(14) Surgery Surgery can help increase lung volume and overall long-term  prognosis in patients who have decreased preoperative lung volumes(19) Authors of a retrospective study in 2018 found that a surgical procedure of using a surgical procedure of anterior release, instrumentation, and fusion using an autogenous rib graftshow good outcomes for healthrelated  quality of life (HRQoL), pain scores, and functional activities (23)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: An inclinometer (or scoliometer) assessment may be completed and results used to determine if an X-ray  is indicated(2)

MRI or a bone scan may be used to rule out other conditions.(3) MRI is usually not indicated unless there is pain, a neurologic deficit, or a left thoracic curve associated with an underlying spinal disorder(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational, chiropractic, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Ask if shoe inserts for real or apparent leglength discrepancy have been used

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Any radicular pain?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Rating of symptoms -Scoliosis often becomes painful in adulthood -Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Ask patient about sleep disturbance due to pain. This is not a typical sign or symptom of AIS and may indicate a more insidious condition such as a tumor
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient complain of shortness of breath? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Inquire about family history of scoliosis
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other conditions, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Congenital spine deformity (e.g., hemivertebra), neuromuscular disease (e.g., cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury, or progressive neurological or muscular diseases), osteopathic disorders (e.g., osteomalacia, rickets, or fracture),(1) and local inflammation or infection(3) may cause nonidiopathic scoliosis. Severe scoliosis may result in corpulmonale, right ventricular dysfunction, or pulmonary hypertension
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -School grade level (onsite or home school) -Amount and type of physical activity/participation in sports each week -If the patient works, describe job duties
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient or caregiver report any difficulties with ADLs? Has a brace been prescribed and/or ordered? If so, is it in use? How many hours per day does the patient wear the brace? Does the patient/caregiver have any difficulties with donning and doffing the brace? Is the brace wear schedule functional in the school setting for this child? Does the patient drive?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Note patient’s height, weight, and BMI; document the height of the child’s mother and father, if able –Assess for a leg-length  discrepancy(2)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess fit of brace if applicable
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess single-leg  stance with eyes open and closed. Note asymmetry –Romberg or Sharpened Romberg test may be used –Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) or Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)  balance subscale may also be used for balance assessment
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess independence and safety with basic mobility such as floor to stand transfers, stair negotiation, sit-to-stand, and car transfers
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess gait and note any asymmetry, including asymmetrical arm swing and trunk rotationAssess joint mobility and note any areas of hypomobility or hypermobilityComplete a fine and gross motor coordination assessment as indicated(2) –The BOT-2  can be used in children and youth aged 4–21  years for gross and fine motor skill assessment
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity and trunk strength per manual muscle testing (MMT) as age-appropriate(2)
observation inspection palpation includi: The paravertebral muscles will have increased tone and stiffness along the concave side of the body (24)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess posture in both sitting and standing positions. Maintaining certain positions for long periods of time may influence the progression of the scoliosis –Posterior posture assessment -Palpate each spinous process. Note convexity of scoliosis and location in spine. Examine and document asymmetry in shoulder height, scapulae, rib cage, iliac crest, and other pelvic prominences –Lateral posture assessment -Evaluate spinal curves. Individuals with scoliosis may present with excessive thoracic kyphosis and lumbar lordosis -Note presence of forward head posture -Craniovertebral angle may be measured to assess forward head posture -The angle between a line drawn from the tragus of the ear to the seventh cervical vertebra and a horizontal line -A lateral photograph may be used to perform the measurement –Asymmetry of rib cage -Convex side of curve—increased space between ribs -Concave side of curve—narrowed space between ribs
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Gross assessment of upper and lower extremities and lumbar ROM. Assess for increased hip adduction; decreased flexibility may be present on the ipsilateral side and abductors may be overstretched(1) –See Special tests specific to diagnosis , below, for spinal screeningEvaluate deep tendon reflexes bilaterally in an effort to rule out neurological involvementAssess ability and safety to perform ADLs
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Nerve root irritation may be present on the concave side(1) –Assess bilateral dermatomes and note any asymmetry/abnormality –Complete a sensory assessment (e.g., light touch, pin prick, two-point  discrimination)(2)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Posterior Trunk Symmetry Index (POTSI)(10) -Assesses body asymmetry in scoliosis patients using several indices for trunk deformity –Cobb angle(10) –Walter Reed Assessment Scale(10) -Body curve -Rib prominence -Flank prominence -Relative position of the head to the rib cage and pelvis  -Relative position of head to pelvis -Shoulder level -Scapular rotation –Adam’s Forward-Bending  Test -Have the patient lean forward at the waist, with his or her back exposed and arms at side. Observe the contours of the rib cage from the front or back for asymmetry

other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Treatment intervention varies depending on severity at diagnosis, rate of progression during puberty, and patient’s perception. Concerns include: –cardiopulmonary dysfunction: A severe curve (> 60°) can result in a progressive reduction in lung function Rule out  (structural vs. nonstructural scoliosis) Leg-length  discrepancy (true or functional) Acute pain rarely is noted; likely other causes if present Local inflammation or infection Habitual or asymmetrical postures(1) Marfan syndrome scoliosis(12)
prognosis: Curve magnitude –The greater the curve at diagnosis, the greater the risk of progression

Age/skeletal maturity –The closer a child is to skeletal maturity, the less the risk of scoliotic advancement(2) -Ossification of the iliac apophysis is evaluated and assigned a Risser stage (0 to 5) -Stage 0 equates to no ossification and stage 5 equates to full fusion
Type of curve –Thoracic and double major curves have 3 times the rate of progression as nonthoracic curves(4)

Recent advancements in genetic assessment have made it possible to evaluate the risk of idiopathic scoliosis progression(5) –Fifty-three  loci have been identified –Polymorphism of selected genes is thought to enable categorization of a patient into a progressive or a stable group
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Refer patient to an orthopedist, preferably a pediatric orthopedist, for an initial evaluation if the patient has not already been seen Orthotist for brace management. This should be discussed with the referring physician –Bracing remains controversial. The authors of some reports advocate for early bracing to prevent surgery, while other authors report that bracing is not an effective means to prevent surgery –There is also controversy over which type of brace is most effective
treatment summary: Specific recommendations include that exercises always be individualized even if performed in groups and that specific exercises be provided to autocorrect the posture in three dimensions, stabilize the corrected posture, and train in ADLs(5)
Exercises should focus on the transversus abdominal (TA) muscle in order to normalize the structural changes of the spine. The TA plays an important role in trunk stability (22)
Nonstructural scoliosis: Treatment consists mainly of correcting conditions that cause compensatory postural changes (e.g, muscle spasm, leg-length  discrepancy)

Structural scoliosis –Bracing -Spinal bracing is generally not utilized in this patient population as it is found to be ineffective and poorly tolerated (29) -Bracing is controversial. The authors of some reports advocate for early bracing to prevent surgery, while other authors report that bracing is not an effective means to prevent surgery. In addition, there is controversy over which type of brace is most effective -A study conducted in Hong Kong showed that bracing affected quality of life negatively(7) -Providing psychosocial support to patients and their families was found to be important to enhance their quality of life as well as their compliance -Good compliance with a conservative treatment program that included bracing and specific exercises was reported to result in significant improvement in curvatures in a study conducted in South Africa(8) -Poor compliance resulted in progression of curvatures and was associated with poor quality of life -Factors affecting compliance need to be identified and may relate to psychosocial coping mechanisms –Therapeutic exercise -Researchers conducting an RCT (N = 47) in Turkey found three-dimensional  Schroth exercises performed in clinic to be superior to a home exercise program at decreasing both Cobb and rotation angles in patients with AIS(20) -Schroth method uses exercises to strengthen and/or lengthen asymmetrical muscles. Exercises consist of posture correction and corrective breathing patterns -Subjects were divided into three groups: Schroth exercise group, home exercise group, and a control group -Subjects in the Schroth exercise group performed exercises 1.5 hours a day 3 times a week. Exercises included spinal elongation, de-rotation,  de-flexion,  stretching, strengthening, and rotational breathing exercises. After 6 weeks the exercises were performed at home -Subjects in the home exercise group received instruction from a physical therapist and were asked to do their exercises at home -The control group received no formal instruction -In a 2014 European study, researchers found that active self-correction,  task-oriented  exercises, and patient education performed until skeletal maturity is reached decreased incidence of spinal deformity and improved quality of life in patients with AIS(16) -Scientific Exercises Approach to Scoliosis (SEAS) consists of exercises that are adapted to each individual patient based on impairments present. These exercises include spinal stabilization, strengthening of anti-gravity  muscles, and balance and coordination activities while maintaining active self-correction  (ASC) (31) -ASC is the basis of SEAS. It may be possible to actively reduce the curve by teaching the patient specific exercises -It is thought that ASC activates a motor neuron reflex corrective response. The patient is taught to autocorrect postures without any external aid

Combined aerobic and resistance training exercise has been shown to improve functional exercise capacity and respiratory outcome measures for patients with AIS (25) –Based on an RCT study of 40 adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis who were randomized to either the aerobic and resistance training group (n = 20) or aerobic exercise only group (n = 20) –Both groups performed their respective activities for 60-minute  training sessions once a week for 12 weeks –Results at the end of 12 weeks show that the group that received both aerobic and resistance training had a significant improvement on the 6MWT and a lower rating of perceived exertion compared to the aerobic-only  group

Participating in a scoliosis-specific  exercise program can help reduce the curve pression in participants with mild AIS (26) –Based on an RCT of 49 participants with mild AIS who were placed in an exercise group (n = 26) or control group (n = 23) –The exercise group performed a 15-minute  home exercise program, 3 days a week,of Schroth-based  exercises in a variety of positions (supine, sitting, side-lying,  prone, and standing) -The Schroth program is a nonsurgical program that uses customed exercises to help restore the curvature of the spine to its natural position (27) -The exercises focus on de-rotations, elongation, and stabilizing in a three-dimensional plane  –After 1-year  follow-up,  the researchers found that the exercise group had smaller curve angles compared to the control group as well as less curve progression

Bracing has been shown to be superior to exercise for corrections of spinal curvature and improvement of body symmetry (28) –Participants were randomly assigned to either the bracing group (n = 30) or exercise group (n = 30) –Those in the bracing group received a rigid TLSO and were asked to wear the brace for 23 hours a day –Those in the exercise group followed SEASprotocol and were asked to perform the exercises once a week for 40 minutes along with a routine home exercise program for 10–15  minutes daily –Results show that those in the bracing group had better results with respect to correction of spinal curvature; however, those in the exercise group had better scores on quality of lifeassessments . improved body image and quality of life: HRQoL: It is important to measure how the patient perceives the impact of scoliosis on his or her quality of life, especiallyafter conservative treatment
Scoliosis Research Society-22  health-related  quality of life questionnaire (SRS-22  HRQL)
Body Esteem Scale for Adolescents and Adults (BESAA)(11)
improved balance reactions: Balance assessment: BOT-2  balance subscale, PBS

maintenance or prevention: It has been the prevailing thought that early detection and treatment intervention results in better outcomes for the patient with scoliosis. However, this statement cannot be fully supported or rejected based on the literature

It is not recommended that specific sports be prescribed as a treatment for idiopathic scoliosis(5) Benefits for the cardiovascular system and musculoskeletal system, weight control, stress management, balance, risk of osteoporosis, and psychosocial well-being  may be derived from exercise participation(5) It is recommended that during brace treatment sports activities are continued, but that contact or highly dynamic sports activities be performed with caution(5)
